runs.text: Read the title, and have students repeat as they point to each word.
Explain that the picture shows a lion cub in the grassland, which is home to many animals. Have students describe the grassland in the picture.
routine. You will prompt students to use this word to talk about the story.
is the area around a living thing.
Example: Some animals can use smell and sound to find food in a dark
look like? Tell your partner about it.
Have students whisper-read the story. Circulate, listen in, and offer corrective feedback.
When completed, ask the following questions to check comprehension. Prompt students to answer each question with a partner before you call on volunteers to answer the question.
Find the word that names the animal that lives in the river. (hippo)
Why doesnt Lena like the baby meerkats home? Find the sentences that answer the question.
What does Lena learn about the environment, or surroundings, where she comes from?
Have you ever lived in a different home? What was it like?
Have students reread the book during independent work time and as a warm-up to the next days lesson.
Read the title, and have students repeat as they point to each word.
Explain that this text has illustrations that show information about earthworms. Though the character is not real, the facts and details about earthworms are.
routine. You will prompt students to use this word to talk about the story.
are food parts that help living things grow.
Example: Fruits and vegetables have many
Ask: Why is it important for kids to eat foods with a lot of
Have students whisper-read the text. Circulate, listen in, and offer corrective feedback.
When completed, ask the following questions to check comprehension. Prompt students to answer each question with a partner before you call on volunteers to answer the question.
Find the words that tell how long most earthworms are. (four inches)
Where do earthworms eat food with nutrients, or minerals? Find the sentence that answers the question.
How is the earthworms poop important to the soil? Explain.
Do you think that earthworms are neat or gross? Did this text change your mind about earthworms? Explain why or why not.
Have students reread the book during independent work time and as a warm-up to the next days lesson.
Have students whisper-read each sentence. Then ask them to chorally read it.
Have students read the sentences to a partner. Then have them switch roles.
Have students write a sentence using the word
. Have students read the sentence to a partner.

Discuss the different end punctuation for sentence 1 (period), sentence 2 (exclamation mark), and sentence 5 (question mark). Model how you change your intonation when reading a question (raise voice at end) or exclamation (read with excitement). Have students echo-read the sentences replicating your intonation.
Read the title. Explain that this is a poem with short lines, rhyming words, and descriptive language.
For the first reading, have students echo-read the poem after you. Then pair students to reread the poem. Partners can switch stanzas during the rereadings.

Prompt students to find all the two-syllable words in the poem and circle them. Then have students chorally read the circled words. Ask them to identify closed syllables and open syllables. Provide support as needed. Ask students questions about the text to confirm understanding.
Say each word, guide students to write it, then proceed to the next word in the sentence.
Provide supports for words that are completely comprised of the phonics skills students have learned.
These supports include sound boxes, tapping the sounds, and so on.
Provide supports for the high-frequency words students have learned.
When completed, have students read the entire sentence aloud.
Write the sentences on the board, and have students self-correct. Take note of errors on each students Student Observation Form.
Read the title, and have students repeat as they point to each word.
Explain that students will read about caves made from acid water and the animals that are able to live there. For these animals, acid caves are their habitat, or natural home.
routine. You will prompt students to use this word to talk about the story.
means to change in order to survive, or live.
Example: Some animals have color-changing fur to help them
Ask: What other ways can animals
Have students whisper-read the text. Circulate, listen in, and offer corrective feedback.
When completed, ask the following questions to check comprehension. Prompt students to answer each question with a partner before you call on volunteers to answer the question.
Find the phrase that describes what an acid cave looks like. (strange planet)
Which animals live in the entrance of the cave? Which animals live deeper in the cave? Find sentences that answer these questions.
How have acid cave animals adapted, or changed, to suit their dark habitats?
What do snottites look like to you? What would you have named them?
Have students reread the book during independent work time and as a warm-up to the next days lesson.
Then ask them to chorally read them.
Have students circle words with open syllables.
Have them point to and read those words to a partner.
Have students write a sentence using the word
Have them read the sentence to a partner.
Discuss the different endings for sentences 3 and 4.
Point out that both sentences are about bats, but sentence 4 provides more information.
Have students identify which words are added to sentence 3 to build sentence 4 (that can fly).
Then have students read both sentences consecutively.
Read the title, and have students repeat as they point to each word.
Explain that the text is about Carlsbad Caverns, a large cave. It includes paragraphs and a diagram. Authors include diagrams to help readers understand the parts of something important to remember.
The paragraphs and diagram work together to help readers understand how the cavern formed.
Guide students through a reading of the selection, including the diagram.
Prompt students to share what they notice and wonder when viewing the diagram.

Read the title, and have students repeat as they point to each word. This is an on-level selection. It is provided to gauge where students are in their reading progress toward grade-level goals. Students might need to listen and follow along with the e-book for support before they read the book on their own.
Explain to students that they will read an informational text about a plant that eats bugs.
You will prompt students to use this word to talk about the story.
means to set off a process.
Example: I pressed the button on the video game to
Have students whisper-read the story. Circulate, listen in, and offer corrective feedback.
When completed, ask the following questions to check comprehension. Prompt students to answer each question with a partner before you call on volunteers to answer the question.
Find two things that a Venus flytrap can eat. (insect, spider)
What triggers, or sets off, the Venus flytrap to close? What happens after that?
Why does the author say that Venus flytraps should never be taken from the wild? Explain.
What interesting plants do you have in your area?
Have students reread the book during independent work time and as a warm-up to the next days lesson.
Read the title, and have students repeat as they point to each word.
Explain that this is an article that includes questions people often ask about the bats at Carlsbad Caverns. Ask students which questions they have about bats.
routine. You will prompt students to use this word to talk about the story.
Example: Visit the beach in September to
Ask: Which foods do you like to eat? Which foods do you
Have students whisper-read the story. Circulate, listen in, and offer corrective feedback
When completed, ask the following questions to check comprehension. Prompt students to answer each question with a partner before you call on volunteers to answer the question.
Find a word that tells how visitors can see the bats and learn about them from spring to fall. (program)
Why do the bats come out at dark? Find the sentences that answer the question.
What things do bats avoid, or stay away from?
The author says that mother bats and babies dont stay out all night. Why do you they go home early? Explain.
Would you like to see the bats at Carlsbad Caverns? Why or why not?
Have students reread the book during independent work time and as a warm-up to the next days lesson.
